comment._content: I believe this photograph can be used under a creative commons license - as such I plan to use it in my forthcoming magazine 'Aubade Magazine' www.flickr.com/groups/aubade/ Many thanks for sharing Chris

comment.author: 49592687@N08
comment._content: I'm pretty sure the camera is a Moy.    It's not exactly like other moy's I have seen (the hinges on th e door facing us are slightly different) but the hand crank is in the correct place and it appears to have a longer lens.  Joe Dunton in the UK has one of these cameras which I once borrowed to use on a music video.      It was all a bit embaressing ... the movement combined with modern filmstock made the images almost indistingishable from the images produced with a modern camera.  The exposure variations and unsteadyness you see in old film are mostly the result of the filmstock rather than the camera.

comment.author: 63148939@N00
comment._content: Makes me appreciate the incredible machines we have today. We stand on the shoulders of people like this. Their experience, feedback and innovation over the years combined with a great deal of intelligence and engineering gave us the marvelous tools we have today. I find it almost unbelievable that this man schlepped this monster camera around for months in subzero weather to capture some of the historic images we have today.
